description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 SweFOR’s protection program aims to contribute to an environment where human rights defenders can strengthen their capacities and can properly implement self-care measures for their impact on Colombia’s democratic development and sustainable peace. In the transition from a context of armed conflict, civil society and human rights defenders play a key role to ensure that the end of hostilities also lead to a more resilient society that can resolve conflicts through non-violent ways. In this sense, it is critical that human rights defenders can work in a hostility-free environment. The program will receive 18 930 367 SEK between 2017-2020.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 SWEFOR:s skyddsprogram syftar till att bidra till en miljö där människorättsförsvarare kan stärka sin kapacitet och på ett effektivt sätt genomföra betydelsefulla åtgärder för deras inverkan på Colombias demokratiska utveckling och hållbara fred. I övergången från kontexten av väpnad konflikt spelar civilsamhället och människorättsförsvarare en nyckelroll för att säkerställa att konfliktens slut också leder till ett mer motståndskraftigt samhälle som kan lösa konflikter på icke-våldsamma sätt. I den meningen är det avgörande att människorättsförsvarare kan arbeta i en fredlig miljö. Programmet får 18 930 367 SEK mellan åren 2017-2020.

Through this project, SweFOR will help strengthen the protection of human rights defenders and social leaders and expand their scope of action. In this way, they will be able to demand greater guarantees in the defense of their rights.

participating-org.narrative: Kristna Fredsrörelsen/SWEFOR/The Swedish Fellowship of Reconciliation

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
15.4 - By 2030, ensure the conservation of mountain ecosystems, including their biodiversity, in order to enhance their capacity to provide benefits that are essential for sustainable development.
15.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att bevara bergsekosystemen, inklusive deras biologiska mångfald, i syfte att öka deras förmåga att producera nytta som behövs för en hållbar utveckling.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.

description.narrative: Context 2019 was a negative year in terms of security and protection for human rights defenders. 250 social leaders were murdered over the course of the year. In many cases, there was a change in the configuration of illegal armed actors in the territory, thus rendering the identification of potential threats to communities much more difficult to manage. Elections held in October also led to an increase in violence, which is why many of the accompanied organizations were unable to carry out field visits during this month. Likewise, the country experienced nationwide social protests during the month of November. One of the agenda items in these protests was the murder of social leaders and the poor results in the implementation of the Peace Accord. Overall, SweFOR observed a lack of political will from the current administration to counter some of the main threats and challenges observed by human rights defenders and social leaders. SweFOR’s work is divided into four main outcomes: (1) decrease threats and aggressions against human right defenders, (2) increase the commitment of responsible stakeholders for protection measures, (3) strengthened systems and culture of non-violent self-protection, and (4) increased institutional capacity of the program. Despite an increasingly dire scenario for human rights defenders, SweFOR has made progress towards fulfilling target outcomes during 2019. 1. Decrease threats and aggressions against human right defenders SweFOR estimates that the level of threats and harassment towards accompanied persons/organizations (APOs) has decreased by 10-20% thanks to its efforts. Similarly, 100% of APOs affirms that SweFOR’s support protects their space of action. CCNP, COCOMACIA, and Leyner Palacios highlight SweFOR’s work, but in their cases, it is not possible to say that overall threats and harassments have decreased. On the contrary, for COCOMACIA, these have increased. As such, for the APOs mentioned above, SweFOR’s accompaniment has been particularly useful in protecting their space of action and allowing them to continue carrying out their work despite an increase in threats. A challenge for SweFOR has been the increased risk for young people in the COCOMACIA territories. SweFOR is unable to deter new threats like forced recruitment, an increase in drug and weapons use, and their use as drug mules by gangs and illegal armed groups. For Leyner Palacios, however, SweFOR’s accompaniment has been vital and he is quoted as saying that “without SweFOR’s presence, perhaps he would have been killed”. CCNPB similarly states that SweFOR’s presence has quashed delegitimizing efforts and rumors against its work in El Porvenir, Vichada. SweFOR’s communication and persuasion efforts with authorities and armed stakeholders provide a level of protection and a possibility for CCNPB to meet with international and public actors and the armed forces as well. In 2019, SweFOR began working with Sisma Mujer. This organization reported positive results immediately, stating that SweFOR’s accompaniment provided visibility to a difficult case regarding threats to the organization, and made the Judge more attentive to the details surrounding the file. In total, SweFOR provided accompaniment to 56 persons (50% women), and 7 organizations (4 in Bogotá, 3 in Chocó). SweFOR carried out 127 accompaniments, which represents 90% of its total goal (140). 2. Increase the commitment of responsible stakeholders for protection measures In comparison to the others, Outcome 2 obtained the weakest results. For example, SweFOR was unable to achieve any results in the fulfillment of sentences and laws for the rights of the individuals accompanied. That said, SweFOR was able to influence 4 statements in favor of the protection of its APOs and carried out strategic dialogue regarding these APOs with public institutions. Similarly, in contrast to 2018, where it received 20 answers to its queries regarding the situation of human rights, during 2019, SweFOR was only able to obtain answers from 8 public institutions. SweFOR, however, exceeded its expectations in providing support to APOs in its lobbying and incidence efforts. It highlighted Leyner Palacios’s European tour, as he was able to give visibility to the persistent and deteriorating conflict in Chocó at an international level. 3. Strengthened systems and culture of non-violent self-protection CCNPB recognizes that the protection workshops provided by SweFOR inspired them to draft an internal policy to better handle collective and individual responsibilities. Other organizations, like FAU, COCOMACIA, and Paz y Alianza are incorporating the information learned in these workshops in routines, travel monitoring activities, and other protection protocols. 40% of organizations have received more than one workshop, and the remaining 60% received only one. SweFOR is finding that organizations would rather receive specific support pertaining to specific situations rather than a more holistic training. Overall, however, 234 persons received training, with 115 receiving more than 1 training: 73.5% were men, 24% women, 2.5% LGBTI, 0.5% indigenous peoples, 12.4% afro descendant. All organizations now have protection strategies and risk analysis tools. One of the lesson learned by SweFOR is that emergency plans or reaction routines are easier to adopt than whole security protocols. 4. Increased institutional capacity of the program In 2019, SweFOR signed an agreement with the Swedish Missionary Council for the financing of 2020 as a “bridge” year. It also signed an agreement with the Swedish Church for 2020. This demonstrates that, in securing funding from sources beside Sida Colombia, SweFOR has sufficient resources to function at least for the coming year. With regards to staffing, SweFOR is considered an attractive employer. It received 187 applications for 8 positions in Colombia. In terms of diversity, the majority of observers are women (13% are men in Bogotá and 25% in Chocó). That said, 5 out of 8 observers did not renew their contracts for 2020. SweFOR explains this has mainly to do with workplace fatigue, as most of them had already completed one or two years as members of PBI in the country. SweFOR also encountered challenges with obtaining visas for its international observers. Despite the Swedish Embassy and other Embassies’ efforts, key staff visas were denied by the Colombian government. This resulted in extra legal fees, and air fare and travel costs. Even with the challenges that SweFOR has faced, overall, it has been able to adapt to the difficult circumstances surrounding its work and is still very much a relevant partner for Sida and for key human rights organizations in Colombia.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
